Caption: Fig. 1. INVISQUE system showing two clusters. One showing ʻinformation visualizationʼ and the other showing ʻStuart K. Cardʼ.

Fig. 3. The figure shows the initial string search for ʻinformation visualizationʼ towards the left side of the screen, the newly combined cluster (Boolean OR) using ʻinformationʼ and ʻvisualizationʼ on the right side, and finally the initial keywords preserved at the top left corner of the screen (minimized to optimize space).

Fig. 4. The figure a) Shows participant P6 attempting to initiate a new been highlighted in red. Further to this the publications are brought to search using metadata (keyword) by dragging the topic ʻinteraction the foreground, b) When observing the scatter plot, the publications designʼ towards the canvas, b) Shows the newly initiated ʻinteraction representing ʻStuart K. Cardʼ noted by red dots zoomed in. designʼ card set on the canvas next to ʻinformation visulizationʼ.

Fig. 5: a) An information cluster with ʻinformation visualizationʼ ordered by y(citation), which visually converts into the height of the index card and height represented in the scatter plot; x (year), which visually organize the index cards left to right by descending order of year. b) A participant changes the x axis to represent citation to visually observe the highly cited publications.

Fig. 6. a) An ʻinformation visualizationʼ cluster where the participant is observing ʻStuart K. Cardʼ by highlighting the author. The participant observes two of the index cards, authored by ʻStuart K. Cardʼ, have been highlighted in red. Further to this the publications are brought to the foreground, b) When observing the scatter plot, the publications representing ʻStuart K. Cardʼ noted by red dots zoomed in.
Fig. 9. Shows participant P1 manually taking note of his candidates of interest and filtering the data using the participant determined threshold to see if there is an effect on the selection.

Fig. 8. Participant P2 observes that the boxed index cards do not contain information visualization, in the keyword, title or abstract. This indicates a discrepancy in the data that does not fit with his/her previous beliefs.

Fig. 7. Participant P3 evaluates a candidate ʻinfluencerʼ by exploring different views of a corresponding card set using system functions: a) Performs a Boolean AND operation to identify cards relevant to ʻStuart K. Cardʼ and ʻinformation visualizationʼ; b) Organising the card set in chronological (x axis is citation), making visible the active duration of ʻStuart K. Cardʼ on the topic; c) Identifying gaps in publication years. The participant sees that ʻStuart K. Cardʼ does not have a publication in the collection between during 1994 to 2000); d) Identifying highly cited publications by ordering the data by x:citation and y:citation.
Fig. 10. Participant P2 opens all the potential influential author collections to compare them (Peter Pirolli, Andy Cockburn, Ed H. Chi, and Stuart K. Card).

Fig. 11. An illustration of how participant P3 organised the screen: a) Preserving initial topic searches (ʻinformationʼ,ʼ visualizationʼ,ʼ information visualizationʼ); b) Card sets corresponding to candidates less likely to be influential; c) Base working set (ʻinformationʼ and ʻvisualizationʼ); d) An active workspace for card sets currently being explored (Stuart K. Card), and; e) Storing worked card sets representing candidate field leaders (Peter Pirolli and George G. Robertson).
